name: INTRO TO LAW & LEG PROC

values.comments:
Legal Studies 101 presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included.  

The course content is described as “extremely interesting” and beneficial for both majors and non-majors alike.  One student noted that “the material itself is useful for everyday applications” and is also practical for “developing a much needed ability to think through and solve problems.”  The content involves weekly readings and class discussions, during which participation from every student is required. According to another former class member, the course provided “fresh insights and perspectives on global issues.”

Opinions on Professor Nichols’ teaching style varied. A majority found him to be “brilliant and thoroughly engaging” and one student noted that he had an “extraordinary ability to get students involved and actively interested in the material.”  A second student described him as “strict” but also as someone who “really cares about what the students think.”  Another student found his “knowledge of law extensive and very thorough.”  His common practice of engaging in cold calls was described by one as a “tough, but fair” teaching method that “keeps you on your toes,” while ensuring students kept up with the readings.  Nevertheless, a few students do note that Professor Nichols’ teaching style and choice of cold-calling “can be really harsh.” A small group of students felt “uncomfortable” and “nervous.”  Many students met Professor Nichols’ “tough attitude and high expectations” and found him to be “an amazing professor.”

This course is an excellent option for anyone interested in learning about the legal system, regardless of whether they are in a related major.  Exams were described by one student as “quite difficult” because it was hard to prepare for all of the “hypotheticals contained within them.”  Although a decent amount of reading is required for this course, students do place a high value on the readings assigned and most learn a lot from them.  Because of Professor Nichols’ practice of cold calling and high standard for classroom etiquette (arriving on time, not eating or drinking in class, etc.), this is a class that does require active engagement and thorough preparation each week. This course has no prerequisites.

Legal Studies 101 presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. The second half of the semester consists of an in-depth examination of contract law.

Students described LGST 101 as a “great” course with “a lot of valuable information.” Students found the class to be both interesting and useful. For the final project, students break up into teams to negotiate and draft an employment contract, which students described as “a fantastic experience.”

Students praised Professor Marston for being interesting and knowledgeable, as well as encouraging. They reported that she not only cares about her students understanding and success in the class, but also that she was one of the few professors interested in “her students' personal lives and extracurricular pursuits too.” Her enthusiasm and energy during lectures was appreciated by students, and helped to bring dry topics to life. Her expertise on contracts made her an extremely knowledgeable source for this part of the course. Professor Marston cold-calls students during the second half of the semester, so it was important that students kept up with the material and prepared for these instances.

Most students in this class were Wharton students, who took it to fill the societal environment general requirement. Students found the exams to be extremely challenging, but reported that, “they are not impossible if you really put in the time to understand the material.” The class ended before finals period, which was helpful for students with a difficult finals course load. Overall, students enjoyed this course, despite the difficulty. As one student reported, even though it was my lowest grade of their semester, that they “enjoyed this class the most and learned the most from it as compared to the other classes that semester.”

Legal Studies 101 presents law as an evolving social institution, with special emphasis on the legal regulation of business. It considers basic concepts of law and legal process, in the U.S. and other legal systems, and introduces the fundamentals of rigorous legal analysis. An in-depth examination of contract law is included. 

Students “really enjoyed the course” and a few students commented that LGST 101 was “one of the best classes at Penn.” Students recommended this course to both majors and non-majors because of their love for the class. Most commented that exams are based mostly on lecture, so buying the course-pack is “unnecessary.” One student described the course as “an excellent overview of law in America.” 

Students had only great things to say about Professor Miller. They commented that he “is the best professor they have had at Penn so far” and that he was “engaging and always had funny stories to share with the class.” Students also commented that Professor Miller “did a superb job of making tough legal concepts very understandable.” Some students did convey some concern about his accessibility because his office hours were so early in the morning. However, students believed that the content was “straightforward.” 

This course had a very light workload. Students commented that this was one of their lighter classes because the readings were not necessary to excel in the class.
